Lars Boering
Photopreneur, advisor specialized in photography, teacher and consultant. Managing Director at World Press Photo Foundation.
Mar 4

Beyond the World Press Photo contests

Some thoughts on diversity, debate and trust in the visual journalism community

Well, it’s done.

The winners of the World Press Photo Contest have been judged. The more than 80,000 images entered to the photo contest have been whittled down to the fantastic collection of 309 winning images on our website. And this year, for the first time, the seventh annual Digital Storytelling Contest (previously known as the Multimedia Contest), was judged at the same time, with the international jury selecting 12 incredible winning productions in four categories. Together, these galleries showcase the best visual journalism of the year.

The contests are the foundation of World Press Photo, but the World Press Photo Foundation has become much more than the contests. We develop and support visual journalism and storytelling through education, research and new projects. It bears mentioning, though, that the contests (as well as their aftermath) also bring important issues to the fore that can be highlighted and drawn into our year-round worldwide efforts.

One such vital issue is diversity. We go to a lot of effort to get a globally representative group of entrants and have them judged by an equally diverse peer group of professionals. This year 5,034 photographers from 126 different countries entered, and the 45 winners came from 25 countries, with, for the first time, photographers from Pakistan, the Philippines and Romania winning.

However, as the analysis in our 2017 Technical Report shows, we — and the industry as a whole — have a long way to go before we can be satisfied. For the last three years, women have comprised only 15 percent of entrants. And while we don’t yet know if that percentage is representative of the female population of professional photojournalism, we want to do better. So we’ve started a partnership with the International Women’s Media Foundation (amongst others) to address this. In addition, we applaud the efforts of womenphotograph.com and are contributing in whatever way we can to draw attention to their efforts. We feel that these partnerships and initiatives come directly from our efforts to make these issues part of the conversation.

Even more worrying to me is the fact that large populations of the world are severely underrepresented in the contest. Once again this year, African entrants to our photo contest comprise only 2 percent of the total. This is unacceptable. We’ve made a start in supporting work in the region through the African Photojournalism Database in partnership with Everyday Africa, and the satellite masterclass we’ve run in East Africa and West Africa as a pilot project with external funding.

Without a doubt, the talent is there. This is evident in the great stories we are publishing here on Witness from the Masterclass East Africa. (I seriously suggest you go see them in The Stories section!) Our mission in this area is to enable what exists and connect it to the international media economy, as we do through the African Photojournalism Database on Blink. We know these efforts are already leading to paid work for participants. What we want to achieve is a long-term commitment to partnerships that enable people to develop sustainable careers.

There should never be an excuse to say we can’t find someone local to shoot work or send on an assignment.

Something else that this year’s contest demonstrated was both the great value of debate in the visual journalism community — which we want to encourage and enable — and the limitations of how some debate is currently conducted.

Selecting the World Press Photo of the Year is always a difficult business. How can one image emerge from the tens of thousands? Which one will be seen above all others as meeting the requirement — honoring “the photographer whose visual creativity and skills made a picture that captures or represents an event or issue of great journalistic importance in that year”? There are so many contingencies at work. Who entered what work? Who is on the juries, and how do they develop their approach? And remember that the jury, though selected by the organization, operates independently. (My staff and I can watch, but have no vote.)

There was a debate this year about Burhan Ozbilici’s dramatic winner, some of it inspired by the chair of this year’s general jury. It is not unusual for chairs to find themselves on the losing side in a close jury vote, but it is unusual for them to feel the need to publicly declare they had to distance themselves from the winner. To abandon your fellow jury members like that feels a bit awkward to me. But to be fair to Stuart Franklin, he correctly and publicly recognized the bravery and skill of Burhan as an experienced photographer. There is quite a lot to Stuart’s critique, but I’m in substantial disagreement with its essence. As J.M. Colberg tweeted:

There’s an important debate to be had about how images do or don’t have certain political effects, and we definitely encourage that debate. But if you think a photograph of an assassination — which the photographer accidentally happened upon while attending an out-of-the-way event — is the same as a terrorist group producing their own propaganda images of death, you’ve failed to appreciate the very different circumstances and context of each situation. One is premeditated and captured by chance; the other is staged and presented by the perpetrators. My point here is if we start to say that journalists have become instruments of terrorism just because they are present and photograph it, we are getting dangerously close to saying journalism can’t do its job anymore.

The opinions of the majority of jurors who supported Burhan’s winning photograph have gotten a little lost in the debate, and are worthy of equal attention. Mary Calvert, who rightly stressed that the jury “was awarding the photographer, not the crime,” argued:

“Those who disagree [with the choice] have argued that the murder was premeditated and staged for the cameras and that the photograph may glorify terrorism and contribute to more violent behavior.
By this line of reasoning, we should never publish photographs of terrorist attacks. Applying this litmus test to past events suggest that it was irresponsible to publish images of the 9–11 attack on the US, or the Charlie Hebdo and nightclub attacks in Paris, or the bus bombings in London, or the shootings in Canada or Mumbai or Madrid. Terrorists know that everyone carries a camera; well-trained and equipped news crews are no longer necessary to promote their agendas.
All acts of terrorism are intended to draw the attention of the press and the public. So we shouldn’t cover terrorist attacks because we are giving the terrorists what they want? Quite to the contrary, I believe it is our duty as journalists to bear witness and show the world how completely abhorrent, deviant and sick these terrorists are in their violence.”

Tanya Habjouqa also had some thoughtful observations:

“There can be no doubt that Burhan Özbilici’s horrifically gripping image of the slain Russian ambassador is the epitome of classic spot journalism. To simply celebrate the photographer’s composition and bravery does not do it justice…This image is thought provoking and prompts debate about where we are in media today, and ethical considerations. Beyond the stylistic, beyond the pulp, this moment captured on camera, goes beyond the actual frame itself and pushes the terrible story of Aleppo into the public domain in a way that other images don’t. The triumphant outrage of assassin Mert Altıntaş and the singular image of Aylan Kurdi are connected and speak to the horrific violence happening in Syria and its dreadful repercussions. At the same time, this image talks to me about Russia, and its role in the conflict — while all focused on the victorious outrage of the assassin. But I couldn’t help feeling a tenderness looking at the slain ambassador, Andrei Karlov. His undignified death, that left his scuffed shoes for the entire world to see…. his glasses flung in a corner, gave small visual clues to the man.”

Christian Ziegler, the chair of the nature jury raised a different issue concerning all the winners that we need to seriously contemplate. Talking about Brent Stirton’s powerful “Rhino Wars” story, Christian pondered how we could get media focused on the environment:

“So often news focuses on humanitarian disasters but we are systematically killing tigers, lions, elephants and rhinos, and no one is paying enough attention. Currently there are less than 3,000 black rhino left in the wild. In 1970, there were 63,000. They will soon be extinct.”

Calling attention to the environmental challenges in our world, and the role visual journalism can play in creating both empathy and action — especially when environmental science seems to be under political attack — is something we need to urgently address. Should there be a separate competition on this topic? Should we be running workshops and developing projects on how to tell this story? How can we help? We urge you to share your thoughts on this with us.

Whatever our individual positions in these debates, they were conducted with respect and out of concern for the substance. I have to be honest, though, and say that too much of the social media commentary around visual journalism — and I’m talking here about more than the commentary on our contests — is often so shallow and most of the time so unproductive.

I often say to people that photography needs to grow up. By that, I mean we have to avoid the hasty condemnations, ill-informed denunciations and clichéd declarations. Instead, let’s always begin by asking questions that show we are not afraid to reveal our uncertainties. After that, we need to be sure we have evidence of the arguments we are making. Isn’t that at the core of journalism and the thing to do? Let’s apply the same rules to ourselves when we feel the urge to participate in debate or when we share our opinions. And let’s stop making things so personal. It is not about me and you. It should always be about us and how we move things forward.

We live in a time when too many are cavalier with the facts, and the visual journalism community can not and must not accept that. Indeed, this time is marked for the worse by the fact ‘post-truth’ was Oxford Dictionaries’ Word of the Year for 2016. But I don’t believe we live in a post-truth era.

We know accuracy and fairness matters because the millions who see our exhibitions around the world tell us two important things: The first is that, despite the popular view that we are inundated with images, the audience tell us that they are seeing three quarters (!) of the photographs and stories shown for the first time. The second, and most important, thing is that they value those photographs and stories because they know they can trust what they see.

The sentiment expressed in The New York Times’ recent advertising campaign strikes a chord with us: “the truth is…hard; hard to find; hard to know; more important now than ever.” We have confronted the difficulty of finding and knowing what is true very recently, following allegations against the second place Long-Term Project’s winner, Hossein Fatemi’s “An Iranian Journey.” This was the first time new procedures for handling these cases, introduced in 2016, came into play. We have detailed what happened in the final section of our 2017 Technical Report. [Update 22 March 2017 — we published an additional statement on this case summarising the issues.] In short, the accusations were taken very seriously, we immediately commissioned a respected and independent investigator, he interviewed both the photographer and individuals who were present during the shooting of the work and are primary sources of information (interviews that had to be done and reported confidentially to ensure people could speak freely), and the results were presented to a jury to decide. They determined that the available evidence did not conclusively substantiate the allegations so there was insufficient evidence to declare a clear breach of our contest entry rules. It was a difficult decision for them to make. It has also been quite tough explaining this to all concerned, given that we cannot break the commitment of confidentiality given to the sources. But we have a good process now, it worked well, and we will always be driven by the available evidence.

Trust is at the heart of what we do and can never be taken lightly. This will apply to our planned new contest later this year. I set out the basic thinking in an interview last November, and we will announce details soon. Some people in our often fevered social media photography bubble jumped on the fact they thought we were going to have “a contest without rules”. That isn’t true and, although this contest will allow all sorts of creative approaches that are currently being published by respected media organizations, we will look for genuine stories about actual events and real people told in imaginative ways. They will all have one cardinal requirement: entrants will have to be totally transparent about what they do and why. That way, the purpose will be clear and no one can be misled. For us, in all areas, as much transparency as possible is one of the key principles that underwrites trust.

Trust is at the core of journalism and good storytelling. It’s what the audience wants, and we should all fight to ensure it is secured and valued.

The final word here should go to our deserving World Press Photo of the Year winner, Burhan Ozbilici:

In the end, I had to say that I had done my bit and now I had a responsibility to get on with my work. But I was very aware that I represented a long tradition of good, independent journalism and good news photos. That made me happy and proud — proud of all good journalists, those living and those who have been killed doing their work, at a time when people are trying to manipulate the media, and the quality of journalism is often ignored.

That’s what it’s all about.
